title: How to Graph Linear Equations Using the Intercepts Method

steps.title: Linear equations will always have two variables, the independent variable and the dependent variable.
steps.content: Linear equations will always have two variables, the independent variable and the dependent variable. Identify both. For the sake of clarity, let the independent be x and the dependent be y. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Set x to zero.
steps.content: Set x to zero. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Solve like a normal equation.
steps.content: Solve like a normal equation. This will generate a coordinate for your y-intercept. First, substitute x to zero. Then, subtract the product from both sides of the equation. Note that the operation you will perform with both sides depends on the sign of your number. In this case the number is zero so we will use its opposite, subtraction. After that, divide three from both sides. And, VOILA! You have the answer. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Put your value in a coordinate pair.
steps.content: Put your value in a coordinate pair. (x,y) Since x=0, your coordinate pair will be similar to: (0,y).

steps.title: Graph the point on a coordinate plane.
steps.content: Graph the point on a coordinate plane. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Repeat steps 2-5, setting y=0 and solving for x.
steps.content: Repeat steps 2-5, setting y=0 and solving for x. Again, since you set y=0, your coordinate pair will look something like: (x,0).

steps.title: Take a straightedge and connect the two points.
steps.content: Take a straightedge and connect the two points. [5] X Research source
